subsc: General finance sector,Banking,Law and justice,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial. Lessons drawn from the
            project are conveyed as follows. The risk of a reemerging
            war remains a dominating factor when assessing a project in
            a post-conflict country. Thus particularly, in the financial
            sector, economic instability, uncertainty, and high
            inflation are factors to be previously assessed, as well as
            the potential delays of necessary reforms to be introduced.
            However, a strong element of the project was the commitment,
            and stability of the implementing agency, which despite the
            absence of Bank visits, changes among team leaders, and
            Government officials, maintained its position throughout
            implementation, thus ensuring institutional memory, and
            preventing an early project closing. The long duration of
            the project (ten years) proved that ambitious goals under
            difficult circumstances, and in a country under economic
            transition, may require more implementation time than
            initially planned. And, technical assistance projects allows
            the Bank to remain engaged in the policy dialogue, beyond
            the immediate project objectives, while Bank project ratings
            can be used effectively as a tool in supervision, given that
            project performance was discussed with the Government, which
            in addition, helped accelerate critical government actions,
            ensuring project outcomes.
